Hi. (a beat) So far so good.  So.  What  should we talk about? How  insecure we were in high  school.  Shirley Votypka, the  first girl I ever felt up.   Health.  What about health?  Did you know that eating six  macadamia nuts is the  equivalent of eating a steak?
Shhhh --
She unbuttons her shirt. And they kiss. FREEZE FRAME on the kiss.  It becomes the silhouette of  a man and a woman kissing.
The silhouette of a man and a woman kissing on a red box of Valentine's Day chocolates and now we see:

A few quick shot of Valentine's Day in Baltimore: shop  windows lined with candy displays of red satin hearts,  lacy Valentine cards, red roses in elaborate floral  arrangements, old ladies selling chocolates, young  ladies selling perfume. A red Valentine's envelope is being tossed on a desk,  and pull back to reveal:
Annie at work.  She looks at the card and opens it.   It's from Walter.  She smiles.  Looks up.  There's  Becky.
You're going to miss the train.
No, I'm not. (she starts assembling  her things)
What are your plans in New  York?
We're going to the Rainbow Room  and the symphony tomorrow night.
I love the symphony.

(cheerfully) I hate it. (she stands to go,  starts toward the  elevator) I'm so happy, Becky.  Finally I  feel happy.  This is right.   This is real.  Everything else  is what happens when you watch  too many movies and completely  lose sight of what counts. (as she steps into  elevator) Please don't tell anyone about  what happened.  "Sleepless in  Seattle" is history.

Annie through the train window as the train starts to  move out of the station. MAP OF THE UNITED STATES. The map we saw at the beginning of the movie, as the  light dims in Baltimore and a light goes on in New York.
Annie steps out of a cab.
Walter opens the door to a beautiful suite.  A bouquet  of flowers sits on the desk.  A bucket of champagne. Annie throws herself into his arms. Walter sneezes.
And pull back to reveal that it's a shot from "An Affair  To Remember." And pull back to reveal:
JONAH is watching with his little girlfriend JESSICA,  who's crying.
(weeping) This is the best movie I've  ever seen in my life.
I don't get it.
You have to go to her, Jonah.   You have to find her.
Jonah nods.  But he isn't sure how he's going to do it.
Do you know how much it costs  to go to New York?
Nobody knows.  It changes  practically every day.  How  much money do you have?
Eighty dollars.
I have forty-two.  So that  would definitely cover  taxicabs, I think.
But how am I going to get  there?
Honey, I'm going out for a few  minutes. (sticking her head in  the door to the living  room) Could you keep an eye on things  out front till I get back?
Jessica looks over at Jonah.
Sure.
Jessica is working on the computer.  She punches Jonah's  name into it.
Do you want an aisle or a  window seat?
Window.
Do you want a fruit plate?
I don't know.  Do I?
(shrugs) I'd rather die than eat on an  airplane. (beat) I'm telling them you're twelve  so you can fly unaccompanied  and they won't make you be  carried around by a stewardess  and everything.
Jonah nods. Now Jessica takes a ticket form out of the desk and  starts to fill it out for Jonah.

formed by two dancers bending over backwards, awash in  pink light and spotlighted in white. Walter and Annie are among a few other people -- couples  mostly -- looking in the windows.  Each one a variation  on the heart motif.  They move to a window -- "Broken  Heart" -- burnished metal, with tow cherubs flying out  of the wound in the middle.
in the Broken Heart window. They're both in their own worlds.  Then they both start  to speak at once.  They stop.  Annie looks at Walter.
You go.
Ever since Christmas, you've  been different.  Kind of  distracted, distant.  But I  feel like you're coming back  from wherever you were.
I am. (she smiles at him) I was just... I just got... I  think I got nervous.  It's  normal, right? Don't you ever  feel nervous about, you know?
What?
About forever.
No.
Well, I did.  And you know what  I think? I think that it was  almost... too perfect.
As Annie and Walter walk through the jewelry department  to the elevator.
I started to wonder whether we  were the human equivalent of  two rights making a wrong, you  know?
Walter has no idea what she means, but he's completely  good-natured about it.
Annie and Walter are walking around the floor, followed  by a SALESWOMAN who is carrying a large white card on  which she is noting their selections.
It was like kismet but not, if  you see what I mean.
Walter's brow furrows slightly.
(continuing) You have to grow up.  You can't  have all these adolescent  dreams about how exciting your  life is going to be --
Walter starting to look puzzled.
(continuing) Don't hate me but I love this  pattern.
You couldn't.
I do.
It's just like my grandmother's  china.
How many place settings should  I put down?
Ten.
Walter beams at her.
Exactly.  Eight is too few and  twelve is too many.
The SALESWOMAN writes a "10" on the big sheet of paper.

As Annie and Walter come out of the elevator on the  ground floor and WALTER stops for a moment at the  Jewelry Repair department, reappears with a little blue  Tiffany's box he gives to Annie. Annie opens it. Inside is a lovely antique diamond ring.
Walter.
It was my mother's.

It's so beautiful.  It's just  what I would have picked out if  I'd had every ring in the world  to choose from. (as she slips the ring  onto her finger) You see what I mean.  There are  people who would like a  relationship to be full of  surprises, but I am not one of  them. (as she starts out the  door with Walter  behind, thinking about  what she has just  said) Surprises are highly overrated.
As they go out the door to:
As they start down the street and go off into the  distance.

(continuing) Promise me something, Walter.   Promise me you will never have  a surprise party for me.  Ever.   You know what happens, you walk  in the door in some horrible  sweater you put on that morning,  and there are hundreds of people  in their best clothes shouting  "Surprise!"
Sam's got a suitcase on the bed, packing.  Jonah is  standing in the doorway, watching. He goes to his desk looking for something but can't find  it.  He tries a few drawers.
Have you seen my wallet?
It might be in the kitchen.
Sam doesn't remember leaving it in the kitchen.
I'm only going to be away one  night, okay, and Clarise will  be here.  You'll have a swell  time.  You'll watch a little  Geraldo, some Nightmare on Elm  Street 12, I'll never know.
Are you going with her?
Yes.
Jonah walks out of Sam's bedroom and we hear the door to  his bedroom slam shut.
Starting to boil. He walks into --
And open the door to Jonah's room.
I have to have a life.  I have  to do things that I want with  people my own age.  It's none  of your business who I am going  out with.  I don't give a good  goddam if you're angry --
(holding up Annie's  letter) This is the one I like.
Sam starts back to his bedroom.
I don't care who you like.   It's who I like.  But the truth  is you're never going to like  anyone because it isn't your  mother.
Sam throws a pair of socks into the suitcase.
(yelling) Fine.  I won't say anything.   You can marry Count Dracula.
Thank you, Jonah.  But the  point is, I am not asking  permission.
(yelling) What's wrong with Annie?
(emphasizing every  word) Shut up.
Jonah appears at the doorway.
Shut up?  Shut up???  Mom never  did that.  Mom never said shut  up to me.  Mom never yelled at  me.
This conversation is finished.
You said we could go to New  York.
Did not.
Did too.
I can't know what I said, but  we're not going.
(crossing his arms  across his chest) I'm not leaving this room until  you say yes.
Get out.
No.
Goddammit, I am sick of this  --
Sam picks Jonah up and carries him kicking and screaming  into:
and into:
Put me down.  I hate you, I  hate you --
He throws Jonah on the bed.  Jonah in tears.
I'm sick of this phony  melodramatic bullshit.  I'm  sick of it.
He leaves the room and slams the door.
Jonah weeping as Sam goes back to his bedroom.
The sound of Jonah weeping. Sam sits down on the bed, wiped out.  Hold on him.
As Clarise the babysitter arrives at the houseboat.
Sam and Clarise in the hallway outside Jonah's door.
Jonah?  Clarise is here, okay?  And I'm leaving.
No response.
Jonah? (to Clarise) He's probably still asleep.
He opens the door gently to the room. Jonah's gone.

Sam looks in the bathroom: no Jonah.  In the main cabin. The back deck.  Out onto the docks.  Looking all up and  down.  Clarise coming down the deck -- she's apparently  been looking in the neighborhood.  As she shakes her  head no, Sam goes to the bicycle shed.  Jonah's bike  still there.  Sam stands on the deck.

We see a group of people filing off an airport shuttle  bus.  The sign in front rotates from "Airport" back to  "Marina." Jonah comes down the stairs and steps off with his  Mariners backpack.  He just stands there a beat, looking  around.  Then he goes through the glass doors.
The TICKET CLERK turns back to the counter.
Next.
Jonah steps forward, with his ticket.

Jessica is sitting defiantly in a chair in the middle of  the living room.  She is being interrogated but she is  not going to talk.  There's a clock on the mantel.  Sam  is in the room with Jessica's mother and father.
Jessica, this is not  acceptable.
If you don't tell us right now,  right this minute, I'm going to  kill you.
Jessica rolls her eyes. She looks over the clock on the mantel.  As it ticks  to 8:30:
He's on his way to New York.
What?
How?
(the child of travel  agents) United 597.
Jessica's mother and father are horrified.
Jessica!
When does it leave?
Eight-thirty.
Everyone looks over at the clock.  It says 8:31.   Jessica smiles.
Driving to the airport.
As his car takes the airport exit.
A stewardess bends affectionately over Jonah, ensconced  in the first-class section.  He's got his backpack on  his lap and he's holding it.
Here you go... here's a nice pin  for you, for flying with us.
(completely unmoved,  but polite) Thank you.
You're welcome.  Can I take  that for you?
(clutching it even  tighter) No.
at the reservations desk.  Desperation.
(frantic) He's about this high, 90  pounds, never combs his hair,  Mariner's hat --
(to his colleagues) Anyone check in a  unaccompanied minor on the New  York flight?
I did.
Sam closes his eyes.
I'll kill him. (beat) I have to get to New York as  fast as I can.
We can get you on a flight to  Chicago and you can change  planes --
Starting to punch information into the computer.
How will you be paying for  this?
(taking out his wallet) American Express. (there's no American  Express card in his  wallet) Visa. (beat) I really am going to kill him.
As Sam comes out of the plane from Seattle and dashes  through the concourse, managing to arrive at the plane  for New York at the very last moment.

As Jonah comes out of the plane from Seattle and looks  up to see which way to go.  He looks very small.  Big  New York passengers in a hurry whiz by with their  carryons dangerously flying at their sides.
Jonah stands in a taxi line.
Jonah sits down in the back seat.  Looks up.  A big  bruiser of a CAB DRIVER leans back over the seat, sizing  Jonah up.
Where to?
Empire State Building.
Sam is in an aisle seat.  He closes his eyes and  squeezes them tight.
(to himself) Come on... come on... come on...  COMEONCOMEONCOMEONCOMEONCOMEON...
It looks magnificent in the waning afternoon light.
There it is.
We are watching from:
where Jonah, with his head out the window, regards the  building with awe.
What are you gonna do there,  spit off the top?
No.  I'm gonna meet... (trying to figure out  what to call her) my mother.

Walter and Annie walking toward their table with the  MAITRE D'. Annie sits down, looks at the view.  Walter starts to  sit, revealing a spectacular view of the EMPIRE STATE  BUILDING directly behind him.  Annie's smile fades.
Is something wrong.
Annie shakes her head.
May I get you a drink?
Some champagne?
Fine, fine.
Walter glances back over his shoulder.
Beautiful view, isn't it?
Walter, there's something I  have to tell you --
As Sam rushes out of the terminal.  Desperate. A cab pulls up.  Sam bolts to the head of the line and  muscles his way into the cab.  The other people in line  are irate.
Sorry, this is an emergency.
The cab pulls out to a chorus of verbal abuse.
Empire State Building.
Jonah, carrying his backpack, walks through the majestic  lobby and follows the arrow to the Observation Deck.
Looking down on the observation deck.  The city below.   The tiny figure of Jonah walks into the middle of the  deck.  Looks around.
Sam's cab speeds across the bridge and into Manhattan,  heading for the Empire State Building.

location: TOP OF THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING

text: Jonah is going to take the bull by the horns.  He walks  up to a likely-looking WOMAN.
Hi, I'm Jonah.  Are you Annie?
No. (smiles at him) I'm Cynthia.
He spies another unattached woman.
Excuse me, are you Annie?
A helicopter shot of Annie talking animatedly to Walter. And pull back to reveal that the Rainbow Room is  actually being seen by Jonah through a viewscope in:

Jonah is looking through the viewfinder.  He turns  around, forlorn.  He takes off his backpack and is about  to sit down next to it when Sam bolts into the  observation deck. Jonah leaps into his arms.
You're my family.  You're all  I've got.  What if something  happened to you?
Sam's eyes well up.  Jonah starts to cry.
What if I couldn't get to you?
I was scared of what you were  gonna do.
When I found you?
If I didn't go.
Listen, have I ever done  anything really stupid?
No.
I mean, so far, have I screwed  it up for you?
No.
The two of them hold each other tight.  After a beat:
I can't believe you flew first  class.
It was all they had.
Annie and Walter.  There's champagne in their glasses,  but neither of them has drunk a drop.
I don't know what to say about  it, Walter.  It was a form of  temporary insanity.  But I had  to tell you about it because --
(matter-of-fact) -- it was a betrayal.
Yes.  But it wasn't really.  It  was just...
So what happened?
I told you.  Nothing --
At the top of the Empire State  Building --
I'm not at the top of the  Empire State Building.  I'm  here.

Not really. (beat) Look, Annie, I love you.  Let's  leave that out of it.  I don't  want to be someone you're  settling for.  I don't want to  be someone anyone settles for. (beat) I have a life insurance policy,   I'm fully invested in growth  stocks, I have a paid  subscription to Home Rox  Office, I have no sexual  diseases, I have been steadily  employed in a part of the  economy that isn't soft, I have  expectation in the way of  inherited wealth, I dress  nicely, I am a member of the  private sector, an independent  voter, I don't watch Monday  Night Football, the only thing  wrong with me is that I am  allergic to wheat,  strawberries, penicillin,  pollen, nuts and wool.  There  are plenty of women who see me  as the brass ring.  If you  don't -- marriage is hard  enough without bringing such  low expectations into it, isn't  it?
Annie is nodding.  She wipes a tear from her face.
Oh, Walter.  I don't deserve  you.
I think that's what I'm saying.
Slowly, gingerly, Annie slips the engagement ring off  her finger and hands it to Walter. No bitterness here.  Both of them trying to be gentle  with each other.
You okay?
Yes. (beat) Some people will do anything to  get out of going to a symphony.
This breaks the tension.  Both of them smiles.
Oh!
What?
Look!
Walter turns to look over his shoulder at what Annie  sees:

head_text.subj: THE LIGHTS HAVE JUST GONE ON ON THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING

text: A huge pink and white heart. Walter turns back to Annie.
Go for it.
And as Annie's heart leaps and she's about to bolt.
As Annie comes out to the street and hails a cab. As it screeches off toward Fifth Ave.
The lights are on all over the city. The crowd has thinned out considerably.  Jonah and Sam  are among the last people left.  They gaze out at the  twinkling lights and the ever-darkening sky.
Last call.  Closing time.
Jonah looks at Sam.
This is pretty dumb, wasn't  it?
Sam shrugs.
Big deal.
After a beat.
Maybe we'll get a dog when we  get back.
Okay.
What do you mean, okay?  Wouldn't you like a dog?
Sure.
Sam puts his arm around him, they start toward the  elevator.
Let's go home.
Annie's cab stuck in traffic. As Annie gets out of the cab. She's breaking into a hard run toward the Empire State  Building.

location: LOBBY OF THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING

text: Annie sprints in and over to Information Booth.
Sorry, ma'am, but the elevators  are closed.
(out of breath) No.  Please.  I really need to  get up there.
We're closing up.  No more runs  tonight.
Annie takes a deep breath.  She's hit the end of the  road.  She turns to go but then turns back.
(out of breath) Listen, can I just take a look?  Maybe... maybe... There's  someone I was supposed to  meet... He's probably not  there, but if I don't at least  look I'll always wonder about  it.
The Information Booth Person looks at her.
Cary Grant, right?
You know that movie?
One of my wife's favorites.

location: TOP OF THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING

text: After a few beat the elevator door opens on a very  empty platform.
Sorry, ma'am.  Empty.
Annie slowly walks out.
Can I take a minute?
Go ahead.

She sighs.  Heads for the telescopes.  Looks out at the  twinkling lights below. She casually turns the telescope and suddenly sees  something on the floor. Jonah's Seattle Mariners backpack. She picks it up.  She realizes that it might be...  could be... and opens it.  Inside is a toothbrush and  Jonah's teddy bear.  As she takes out the bear the other  elevator DINGS. Annie looks up as Jonah and Sam exit the elevator.
I left it near the...
And they stop.  There she is.  There they are.  Sam  can't believe it.  It's the mystery woman.
It's you.
It's me?
The one in the street.  I  chased after you.
Are you Annie?
Yes.
(confused)
You're Annie too? She smiles awkwardly.
(indicating the  backpack) Is this yours?
Jonah walks over to her.  He puts his hand out.  She  shakes it solemnly.
I'm Jonah. (nodding back to Sam) That's my dad.  His name is  Sam.
Hi, Jonah.  Sam. (indicating the teddy  bear) And who is this?
Howard.
Howard.
Sam nods.  Smiling.  Starting to put it all together.   Annie smiles.  Still nervous.  No one knows what to do  next.  Just then, one of the elevator operators CLEARS  HIS THROAT.
We better go.
Annie nods. Sam holds out his hand.
Shall we?
Annie slips her hand into his.  It feels comfortable,  natural, right.
Sam?
He looks at her.
It's nice to meet you.
On Annie. On Sam. On Jonah.  He makes a triumphant little double-fist  gesture to himself as the elevator doors close.

WE SEE THE BUILDING from above, all lit up, a romantic  confection, the world's largest Valentine. The CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see the United States  spread out before us, with lights twinkling everywhere. And
